   As a child, I always seemed to struggle with reading and writing. This may seem a shock since I am now majoring in English, but it was not always something I loved. Those little reading assignments where a child must read a sentance and come up with a picture to draw in the space above was always hard for me to comprehend and when I began longer reading assignments, I would be up hours into the night. This lack of interest was not because I dispised my creative nature, but instead was because of my Dyslexia. I never liked playing the typical outside games like tag or hide and seek, but rather the playground became my canvas and my mind wrote the plot to stories and stories of fantastical games. 

   With the help of my friends, we would go on daring adventures every day during recess. Fighting off monsters, saving friends, or surviving disasturous situations was all we wanted to come up with. We would play these plot-based games every day and when rain would shelter us indoors, we would think of intersting props we could create or use for stories to come.

   Every school has their motto, every team their chant, but one that always seemed to stand out to me was what I had heard in my younger years of Junior High School. For a short time, I was a member of the school's band and had heard the saying "Pain is worth the gain" more often than one should have to. Although I was not a committed member of band, I did apply this saying to basketball. With a coach that tended to care more about the players with natural talent, yet had the audacity to punish the hard working players, it was a mindset that was needed to succeed.

Time was fading and I still had over half of the test to go. I would have to stay after again; work through the bell and the sounds of everyone around me packing up for their next class. It's so unfair. Why can't I be like them? I can always hear them speaking and moving about with no concern for my own concentration. Why did they always have to make such a ruckus? Wait, what did I eat for lunch yesterday? Did I have any other homework for tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? Crap, the test test!

   This anxious feeling has always been prominent. The fear of staying in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave and all the students from the next class file in very rarely with concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? We just want to talk, why w

 

 

   As a child, I always seemed to struggle with reading and writing. This may seem a shock since I am now majoring in English, but it was not always something I loved. Those little reading assignments where a child must read a sentence and come up with a picture to draw in the space above was always hard for me to comprehend and when I began longer reading assignments, I would be up hours into the night. This lack of interest was not because I despised my creative nature, but instead was because of my Dyslexia.

   Although I did not enjoy reading for a long period of time, I did love using my creativity to my advantage. I never liked playing the typical outdoor games like tag or hide and seek, but rather the playground became my canvas and my mind wrote the plot to stories and stories of fantastical worlds. With the help of my friends, we would go on daring adventures every day during recess. Fighting off monsters, saving friends, or surviving disastrous situations was all we wanted to come up with. We would play these plot-based games every day and when rain would shelter us indoors, we would think of interesting props we could create or use for stories to come.

   Every school has their motto, every team their chant, but one that always seemed to stand out to me was what I had heard in my younger years of Junior High School. For a short time, I was a member of the school's band and had heard the saying "Pain is worth the gain" more often than one should have to. Although I was not a committed member of band, I did apply this saying to basketball. With a coach that tended to care more about the players with natural talent, yet had the audacity to punish the hard working players, it was a mindset that was needed to succeed.

   It was the first test of the day and all I could focus on was the tick tick ticking of the classroom clock hanging on the wall, the tapping of pencils against the desks and the uncomfortable squeaky chair that seemed to find joy in my discomfort. Time was fading and I still had over half of the test to go. I would have to stay after again; work through the bell and the sounds of everyone around me packing up for their next class. It's so unfair. Why can't I be like them? I can always hear them speaking and moving about with no concern for my own concentration. Why did they always have to make such a ruckus? Wait, did I have homework for any of my classes tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? What did I eat earlier? Crap, focus. I have to finish the test!

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave and all the students from the next class come filing in, very rarely with concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it, if they didn't th what makes their minds so different from my own. 

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementry years. Of course many young children do not find joy in reading, but mine had grown into a hatred. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading it outloud was an even harder struggle. It wasnt until my mother convinced the school to test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didnt like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had learned about the english language starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school.

Wait, did I have homework for any of my classes tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? What did I eat earlier? Crap, focus. I have to finish the test!

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave and all the students from the next class come filing in, very rarely with concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementry years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfactionm seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book outloud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didnt like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had origionally learned about the english language starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. This class helped me grow in ways I never believed I could and because my mother never gave up on my education, I refuse to let her down.

   It was the first test of the day and all I could focus on was the tick tick ticking of the classroom clock hanging on the wall, the tapping of pencils against the desks and the uncomfortable squeaky chair that seemed to find joy in my discomfort. Time was fading and I still had over half of the test to go. I would have to stay after again; work through the bell and the sounds of everyone around me packing up for their next class. It's so unfair. Why can't I be like them? I can always hear them speaking and moving about with no concern for my own concentration. Why did they always have to make such a ruckus? Wait, did I have homework for any of my classes tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? What did I eat earlier? Crap, focus. I have to finish the test!

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave and all the students from the next class come filing in, very rarely with concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementry years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfactionm seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book outloud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didnt like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had origionally learned about the english language starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. This class helped me grow in ways I never believed I could and because my mother never gave up on my education, I refuse to let her down.

   Through my middle school and junior high year, I was a part of the school basketball team. Although I knew I was not a star player, I knew I was one of the hardest working individuals the team had ever seen. I would work on my shot at home, practice at variosus basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I knew I wasn't the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year.

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had origionally learned about the english language starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. This class helped me grow in ways I never believed I could and because my mother never gave up on my education, I refuse to let her down.

   I had developed a mindset that not only affected my effort towards school, but also my energy that was put into other activities like sports. Although I had a strong mindset, it began to change as I attached to a newer, more detramental one. 

   Through my middle school and junior high years, I was a part of the school basketball team. Although I knew I was not a star player, I knew I was one of the hardest working individuals the team had ever seen. I would work on my shot at home, practice at variosus basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I knew I wasn't the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side as I looked up at her. My wrist was throbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee. 

   "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play. The quote I had heard from the band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach theres no promise I would be put back in again.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine." I wasn't. If only I had walked away,

   Tick, tock.

   Tick, tock.

   Tick... Tap tap, tap tap, tap.

   It was the first test of the day and all I could focus on was the tick tick ticking of the classroom clock hanging on the wall, the tapping of pencils against the desks and the uncomfortable squeaky chair that seemed to find joy in my discomfort. Time was fading and I still had over half of the test to go. I would have to stay after again; work through the bell and the sounds of everyone around me packing up for their next class. It's so unfair. Why can't I be like them? I can always hear them speaking and moving about with no concern for my own concentration. Why did they always have to make such a ruckus? Wait, did I have homework for any of my classes tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? What did I eat earlier? Crap, focus. I have to finish the test!

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave and all the students from the next class come filing in, very rarely with concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementry years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfactionm seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book outloud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didnt like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had origionally learned about the english language starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. This class helped me grow in ways I never believed I could and because my mother never gave up on my education, I refuse to let her down.

   I had developed a mindset that not only affected my effort towards school, but also my energy that was put into other activities like sports. Although I had a strong mindset, it began to change as I attached to a newer, more detramental one. 

   Through my middle school and junior high years, I was a part of the school basketball team. Although I knew I was not a star player, I knew I was one of the hardest working individuals the team had ever seen. I would work on my shot at home, practice at variosus basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I knew I wasn't the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side as I looked up at her. Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The refferee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play. The quote I had heard from the band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach theres no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only timperary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine." I wasn't. If only I had walked away in that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldnt have had to go through such trials.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain"

   Tick, tock.

   Tick, tock.

   Tick... Tap tap, tap tap, tap.

   It was the first test of the day and all I could focus on was the tick tick ticking of the classroom clock hanging on the wall, the tapping of pencils against the desks and the uncomfortable squeaky chair that seemed to find joy in my discomfort. Time was fading and I still had over half of the test to go. I would have to stay after again; work through the bell and the sounds of everyone around me packing up for their next class. It's so unfair. Why can't I be like them? I can always hear them speaking and moving about with no concern for my own concentration. Why did they always have to make such a ruckus? Wait, did I have homework for any of my classes tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? What did I eat earlier? Crap, focus. I have to finish the test!

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave and all the students from the next class come filing in, very rarely with concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementry years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfactionm seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book outloud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didnt like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had origionally learned about the english language starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. This class helped me grow in ways I never believed I could and because my mother never gave up on my education, I refuse to let her down.

   I had developed a mindset that not only affected my effort towards school, but also my energy that was put into other activities like sports. Although I had a strong mindset, it began to change as I attached to a newer, more detramental one. 

   Through my middle school and junior high years, I was a part of the school basketball team. Although I knew I was not a star player, I knew I was one of the hardest working individuals the team had ever seen. I would work on my shot at home, practice at variosus basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I knew I wasn't the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side as I looked up at her. Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The refferee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play. The quote I had heard from the band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach theres no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only timperary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine." I wasn't. If only I had walked away in that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldnt have had to go through such trials.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down the court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear I would have to sit out longer. Two years later

   Tick, tock.

   Tick, tock.

   Tick... Tap tap, tap tap, tap.

   It was the first test of the day and all I could focus on was the tick tick ticking of the classroom clock hanging on the wall, the tapping of pencils against the desks and the uncomfortable squeaky chair that seemed to find joy in my discomfort. Time was fading and I still had over half of the test to go. I would have to stay after again; work through the bell and the sounds of everyone around me packing up for their next class. It's so unfair. Why can't I be like them? I can always hear them speaking and moving about with no concern for my own concentration. Why did they always have to make such a ruckus? Wait, did I have homework for any of my classes tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? What did I eat earlier? Crap, focus. I have to finish the test!

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave and all the students from the next class come filing in, very rarely with concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementry years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfactionm seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book outloud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didnt like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had origionally learned about the english language starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. This class helped me grow in ways I never believed I could and because my mother never gave up on my education, I refuse to let her down.

   I had developed a mindset that not only affected my effort towards school, but also my energy that was put into other activities like sports. Although I had a strong mindset, it began to change as I attached to a newer, more detramental one. 

   Through my middle school and junior high years, I was a part of the school basketball team. Although I knew I was not a star player, I knew I was one of the hardest working individuals the team had ever seen. I would work on my shot at home, practice at variosus basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I knew I wasn't the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side as I looked up at her. Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The refferee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play. The quote I had heard from the band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach theres no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only timperary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine." I wasn't. If only I had walked away in that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldnt have had to go through such trials.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down the court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had went to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my miniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. T

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave and all the students from the next class come filing in, very rarely with concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementry years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfactionm seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book outloud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didnt like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had origionally learned about the english language starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. This class helped me grow in ways I never believed I could and because my mother never gave up on my education, I refuse to let her down.

   I had developed a mindset that not only affected my effort towards school, but also my energy that was put into other activities like sports. Although I had a strong mindset, it began to change as I attached to a newer, more detramental one. 

   Through my middle school and junior high years, I was a part of the school basketball team. Although I knew I was not a star player, I knew I was one of the hardest working individuals the team had ever seen. I would work on my shot at home, practice at variosus basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I knew I wasn't the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side as I looked up at her. Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The refferee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play. The quote I had heard from the band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach theres no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only timperary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine." I wasn't. If only I had walked away in that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldnt have had to go through such trials.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down the court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had went to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my miniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consisticy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until mhy knee would eventually give out.

When the Going Gets Rough

   Tick, tock.

   Tick, tock.

   Tick... Tap tap, tap tap, tap.

   It was the first test of the day and all I could focus on was the tick tick ticking of the classroom clock hanging on the wall, the tapping of pencils against the desks and the uncomfortable squeaky chair that seemed to find joy in my discomfort. Time was fading and I still had over half of the test to go. I would have to stay after again; work through the bell and the sounds of everyone around me packing up for their next class. It's so unfair. Why can't I be like them? I can always hear them speaking and moving about with no concern for my own concentration. Why did they always have to make such a ruckus? Wait, did I have homework for any of my classes tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? What did I eat earlier? Crap, focus. I have to finish the test!

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave and all the students from the next class come filing in, very rarely with concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementry years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfactionm seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book outloud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didnt like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had origionally learned about the english language starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. This class helped me grow in ways I never believed I could and because my mother never gave up on my education, I refuse to let her down.

   I had developed a mindset that not only affected my effort towards school, but also my energy that was put into other activities like sports. Although I had a strong mindset, it began to change as I attached to a newer, more detramental one. 

   Through my middle school and junior high years, I was a part of the school basketball team. Although I knew I was not a star player, I knew I was one of the hardest working individuals the team had ever seen. I would work on my shot at home, practice at variosus basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I knew I wasn't the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side as I looked up at her. Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The refferee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play. The quote I had heard from the band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach theres no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only timperary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine." I wasn't. If only I had walked away in that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldnt have had to go through such trials.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down the court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had went to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my miniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consisticy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until mhy knee would eventually give out.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had went to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my miniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consisticy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until mhy knee would eventually give out.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

When the Going Gets Rough

   Tick, tock.

   Tick, tock.

   Tick... Tap tap, tap tap, tap.

   It was the first test of the day and all I could focus on was the tick tick ticking of the classroom clock hanging on the wall, the tapping of pencils against the desks and the uncomfortable squeaky chair that seemed to find mischevious joy in my discomfort. Time was fading and I still had over half of the test to go. I would have to stay after again; work through the bell and the sounds of everyone around me packing up for their next class. It's so unfair. Why can't I be like them? I can always hear them speaking and moving about with no concern for my own concentration. Why did they always have to make such a ruckus? Wait, did I have homework for any of my classes tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? What did I eat earlier? Crap, focus. I have to finish the test!

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave followed by all the students from the next class come filing in, very rarely with any concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementry years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfactionm seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book outloud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didn't like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had origionally learned about the english language starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. This class helped me grow in ways I never believed I could and because my mother never gave up on my education, I refuse to let her down.

   I had developed a mindset that not only affected my effort towards school, but also my energy that was put into other activities like sports. Although I had a strong mindset, it began to change as I attached to a newer, more detramental one. 

   Through my middle school and junior high years, I was a part of the school basketball team. Although I knew I was not a star player, I did know that I was one of the hardest working individuals o. I would work on my shot at home, practice at variosus basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I knew I wasn't the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side as I looked up at her. Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The refferee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play. The quote I had heard from my schools band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach theres no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only temperary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine." I wasn't. If only I had walked away in that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldnt have had to go through such trials.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down the court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain.    I had went to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consisticy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until mhy knee would eventually give out.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Although I knew I was not a star player, I did know that I was one of the hardest working individuals on the team. I would work on my shot at home, practice at variosus basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I knew I wasn't the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side and I looked up at her at the sound of her concerned voice. Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The refferee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play. The quote I had heard from my schools band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach theres no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only temperary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine." I wasn't. If only I had walked away in that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldn't have had to go through such trials that followed.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down that old basketball court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear that I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had went to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my miniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consisticy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until mhy knee would eventually give out.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   It was the first test of the day and all I could focus on was the tick tick ticking of the classroom clock hanging on the wall, the tapping of pencils against the desks and the uncomfortable squeaky chair that seemed to find mischevious joy in my discomfort. Time was fading and I still had over half of the test to go. I would have to stay after again; work through the bell and the sounds of everyone around me packing up for their next class. It's so unfair. Why can't I be like them? I can always hear them speaking and moving about with no concern for my own concentration. Why did they always have to make such a ruckus? Wait, did I have homework for any of my classes tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? What did I eat earlier? Crap, focus. I have to finish the test!

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave followed by all the students from the next class come filing in, very rarely with any concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementry years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfactionm seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book outloud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didn't like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had origionally learned about the english language starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. This class helped me grow in ways I never believed I could and because my mother never gave up on my education, I refuse to let her down.

   I had developed a mindset that not only affected my effort towards school, but also my energy that was put into other activities like sports. Although I had a strong mindset, it began to change as I attached to a newer, more detramental one. 

   Through my middle school and junior high years, I was a part of the school basketball team. Although I knew I was not a star player, I did know that I was one of the hardest working individuals on the team. I would work on my shot at home, practice at variosus basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I knew I wasn't the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side and I looked up at her at the sound of her concerned voice. Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The refferee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play. The quote I had heard from my schools band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach theres no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only temperary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine." I wasn't. If only I had walked away in that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldn't have had to go through such trials that followed.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down that old basketball court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear that I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had went to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my miniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consisticy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheel chair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   Everything felt out of touch, out of reality. That was until I picked up a and began to write once again. Although I never got too far in my stories, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas. Eventually this grew

Although I knew I was not a star player, I did know that I was one of the hardest working individuals on the team. I would work on my shot at home, practice at variosus basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I knew I wasn't the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side and I looked up at her at the sound of her concerned voice. Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The refferee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play. The quote I had heard from my schools band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach theres no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only temperary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine." I wasn't. If only I had walked away in that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldn't have had to go through such trials that followed.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down that old basketball court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear that I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had went to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my miniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consisticy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheel chair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   Everything felt out of touch, out of reality, that was until I picked up a book again. The words floating across the page, illustrating fantastical worlds of vast civilations and strange abilites came to life. ItAlthough I never got too far in my stories, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas. Eventually this grew

"Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down that old basketball court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheel chair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

The words floating across the page, illustrating fantastical worlds of vast civilations and strange abilites came to life. It played through my mind as a movie would be shown on a screen. I found my motivation. A motivation to write, to read, and to draw. Although I never got too far in my writing, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas that excited me.

   I had went to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my miniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consisticy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheel chair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   Everything felt out of touch, out of reality, that was until I picked up a book again. The words floating across the page, illustrating fantastical worlds of vast civilations and strange abilites came to life. It played through my mind as a movie would be shown on a screen. I found my motivation. A motivation to write, to read, and to draw. Although I never got too far in my writing, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas that excited me. 

   I eventually picked up art and began attempting to draw the characters I created and the worlds I invisioned. None of them were perfect, but then again, neither is anything else in this world.

When the Going Gets Rough

   Tick, tock.

   Tick, tock.

   Tick... Tap tap, tap tap, tap.

   It was the first test of the day and all I could focus on was the tick tick ticking of the classroom clock hanging on the wall, the tapping of pencils against the desks and the uncomfortable squeaky chair that seemed to find mischevious joy in my discomfort. Time was fading and I still had over half of the test to go. I would have to stay after again; work through the bell and the sounds of everyone around me packing up for their next class. It's so unfair. Why can't I be like them? I can always hear them speaking and moving about with no concern for my own concentration. Why did they always have to make such a ruckus? Wait, did I have homework for any of my classes tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? What did I eat earlier? Crap, focus. I have to finish the test!

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave followed by all the students from the next class come filing in, very rarely with any concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementry years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfactionm seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book outloud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didn't like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had origionally learned about the english language starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. This class helped me grow in ways I never believed I could and because my mother never gave up on my education, I refuse to let her down.

   I had developed a mindset that not only affected my effort towards school, but also my energy that was put into other activities like sports. Although I had a strong mindset, it began to change as I attached to a newer, more detramental one. 

   Through my middle school and junior high years, I was a part of the school basketball team. Although I knew I was not a star player, I did know that I was one of the hardest working individuals on the team. I would work on my shot at home, practice at variosus basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I knew I wasn't the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side and I looked up at her at the sound of her concerned voice. Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The refferee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play. The quote I had heard from my schools band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach theres no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only temperary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine." I wasn't. If only I had walked away in that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldn't have had to go through such trials that followed.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down that old basketball court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear that I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had went to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my miniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consisticy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheel chair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   Everything felt out of touch, out of reality, that was until I picked up a book again. The words floating across the page, illustrating fantastical worlds of vast civilations and strange abilites came to life. It played through my mind as a movie would be shown on a screen. I found my motivation. A motivation to write, to read, and to draw. Although I never got too far in my writing, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas that excited me. 

   I eventually picked up art and began attempting to draw the characters I created and the worlds I invisioned. None of them were perfect, but then again, neither is anything else in this world.

   My love for reading gave me an escape from the pains of the real world and opened a new pathway to opprotunities to improve my creative abilities. Without my injury and  my rediscovery of my love for reading and writing, I never would have

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine." I wasn't. If only I had walked away in that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldn't have had to go through such trials that followed.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down that old basketball court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear that I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had went to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my miniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consisticy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheel chair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   Everything felt out of touch, out of reality, that was until I picked up a book again. The words floating across the page, illustrating fantastical worlds of vast civilations and strange abilites came to life. It played through my mind as a movie would be shown on a screen. I found my motivation. A motivation to write, to read, and to draw. Although I never got too far in my writing, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas that excited me. 

   I eventually picked up art and began attempting to draw the characters I created and the worlds I invisioned. None of them were perfect, but then again, neither is anything else in this world.

   My love for reading gave me an escape from the pains of the real world and opened a new pathway to opprotunities to improve my creative abilities. Without my injury and the rediscovery of my love for reading and writing, I never would have gotten over the fact that I would no longer be able to play the sport I had grown up with. Of course I still love the game, my love for reading outweighs all.

   I had developed a mindset that not only affected my effort towards school, but also my energy that was put into other activities like sports. Although I had a strong mindset, it began to change as I attached to a newer, more detramental one. 

   Through my middle school and junior high years, I was a part of the school basketball team. Before games, while everyone was getting in the mindset to play, I would have a book in my hand  Although I knew I was not a star player, I did know that I was one of the hardest working individuals on the team. I would work on my shot at home, practice at variosus basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I knew I wasn't the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side and I looked up at her at the sound of her concerned voice. Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The refferee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play. The quote I had heard from my schools band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach theres no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only temperary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine." I wasn't. If only I had walked away in that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldn't have had to go through such trials that followed.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down that old basketball court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear that I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had went to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my miniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consisticy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheel chair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   Everything felt out of touch, out of reality, that was until I picked up a book again. The words floating across the page, illustrating fantastical worlds of vast civilations and strange abilites came to life. It played through my mind as a movie would be shown on a screen. I found my motivation. A motivation to write, to read, and to draw. Although I never got too far in my writing, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas that excited me. 

   I eventually picked up art and began attempting to draw the characters I created and the worlds I invisioned. None of them were perfect, but then again, neither is anything else in this world.

   My love for reading gave me an escape from the pains of the real world and opened a new pathway to opprotunities to improve my creative abilities. Without my injury and the rediscovery of my love for reading and writing, I never would have gotten over the fact that I would no longer be able to play the sport I had grown up with. Of course I still love the game, my love for reading outweighs all.

When the Going Gets Rough

   Tick, tock.

   Tick, tock.

   Tick... Tap tap, tap tap, tap.

   It was the first test of the day and all I could focus on was the tick tick ticking of the classroom clock hanging on the wall, the tapping of pencils against the desks and the uncomfortable squeaky chair that seemed to find mischevious joy in my discomfort. Time was fading and I still had over half of the test to go. I would have to stay after again; work through the bell and the sounds of everyone around me packing up for their next class. It's so unfair. Why can't I be like them? I can always hear them speaking and moving about with no concern for my own concentration. Why did they always have to make such a ruckus? Wait, did I have homework for any of my classes tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? What did I eat earlier? Crap, focus. I have to finish the test!

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave followed by all the students from the next class come filing in, very rarely with any concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementry years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfactionm seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book outloud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didn't like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had origionally learned about the english language starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. My wrist was throbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The refferee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play. The quote I had heard from my schools band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach theres no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only temperary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine." I wasn't. If only I had walked away in that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldn't have had to go through such trials that followed.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down that old basketball court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear that I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had went to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my miniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consisticy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheel chair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   Everything felt out of touch, out of reality, that was until I picked up a book again. The words floating across the page, illustrating fantastical worlds of vast civilations and strange abilites came to life. It played through my mind as a movie would be shown on a screen. I found my motivation. A motivation to write, to read, and to draw. Although I never got too far in my writing, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas that excited me. 

   I eventually picked up art and began attempting to draw the characters I created and the worlds I invisioned. None of them were perfect, but then again, neither is anything else in this world.

   My love for reading gave me an escape from the pains of the real world and opened a new pathway to opprotunities to improve my creative abilities. Without my injury and the rediscovery of my love for reading and writing, I never would have gotten over the fact that I would no longer be able to play the sport I had grown up with. Of course I still love the game, my love for reading outweighs all.
