Time was fading and I still had over half of the test to go. I would have to stay after again; work through the bell and the sounds of everyone around me packing up for their next class. It's so unfair. Why can't I be like them? I can always hear them speaking and moving about with no concern for my own concentration. Why did they always have to make such a ruckus? Wait, did I have homework for any of my classes tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? What did I eat earlier? Crap, focus. I have to finish the test!

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave followed by all the students from the next class come filing in, very rarely with any concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementry years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfactionm seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book outloud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didn't like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had origionally learned about the english language starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. This class helped me grow in ways I never believed I could and because my mother never gave up on my education, I refuse to let her down.

   I had developed a mindset that not only affected my effort towards school, but also my energy that was put into other activities like sports. Although I had a strong mindset, it began to change as I attached to a newer, more detramental one. 

   Through my middle school and junior high years, I was a part of the school basketball team. Before games, while everyone was getting in the mindset to play, I would have a book in my hand. Everyone thought it was strange that I would read before the games and although I knew how they percieved me, I also knew that I was one of the hardest working individuals on the team. I would work on my shot at home, practice at variosus basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I knew  wasn't the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side and I looked up at her at the sound of her concerned voice. Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The refferee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play. The quote I had heard from my schools band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach theres no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only temperary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine." I wasn't. If only I had walked away in that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldn't have had to go through such trials that followed.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down that old basketball court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear that I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had went to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my miniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consisticy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheel chair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   Everything felt out of touch, out of reality, that was until I picked up a book again. The words floating across the page, illustrating fantastical worlds of vast civilations and strange abilites came to life. It played through my mind as a movie would be shown on a screen. I found my motivation. A motivation to write, to read, and to draw. Although I never got too far in my writing, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas that excited me. 

   I eventually picked up art and began attempting to draw the characters I created and the worlds I invisioned. None of them were perfect, but then again, neither is anything else in this world.

   My love for reading gave me an escape from the pains of the real world and opened a new pathway to opprotunities to improve my creative abilities. Without my injury and the rediscovery of my love for reading and writing, I never would have gotten over the fact that I would no longer be able to play the sport I had grown up with. Of course I still love the game, my love for reading outweighs all.

answerVersions.2023-10-06T05:53:06.765Z:
When the Going Gets Rough

   Tick, tock.

   Tick, tock.

   Tick... Tap tap, tap tap, tap.

   It was the first test of the day and all I could focus on was the tick tick ticking of the classroom clock hanging on the wall, the tapping of pencils against the desks and the uncomfortable squeaky chair that seemed to find mischevious joy in my discomfort. Time was fading and I still had over half of the test to go. I would have to stay after again; work through the bell and the sounds of everyone around me packing up for their next class. It's so unfair. Why can't I be like them? I can always hear them speaking and moving about with no concern for my own concentration. Why did they always have to make such a ruckus? Wait, did I have homework for any of my classes tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? What did I eat earlier? Crap, focus. I have to finish the test!

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave followed by all the students from the next class come filing in, very rarely with any concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementry years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfactionm seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book outloud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didn't like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had origionally learned about the english language starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. This class helped me grow in ways I never believed I could and because my mother never gave up on my education, I refuse to let her down.

   I had developed a mindset that not only affected my effort towards school, but also my energy that was put into other activities like sports. Although I had a strong mindset, it began to change as I attached to a newer, more detramental one. 

   Through my middle school and junior high years, I was a part of the school basketball team. Before games, while everyone was getting in the mindset to play, I would have a book in my hand. Everyone thought it was strange that I would read before the games and although I knew how they percieved me, I also knew that I was one of the hardest working individuals on the team. I would work on my shot at home, practice at variosus basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I may not have been the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side and I looked up at her at the sound of her concerned voice.

   Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The refferee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play.

   The quote I had heard from my schools band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach theres no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only temperary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine."

   I wasn't. If only I had walked away in that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldn't have had to go through such trials that followed.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down that old basketball court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear that I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had went to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my miniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consisticy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheel chair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   Everything felt out of touch, out of reality, that was until I picked up a book again. The words floating across the page, illustrating fantastical worlds of vast civilations and strange abilites came to life. It played through my mind as a movie would be shown on a screen. I found my motivation. A motivation to write, to read, and to draw. Although I never got too far in my writing, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas that excited me. 

   I eventually picked up art and began attempting to draw the characters I created and the worlds I invisioned. None of them were perfect, but then again, neither is anything else in this world.

   My love for reading gave me an escape from the pains of the real world and opened a new pathway to opprotunities to improve my creative abilities. Without my injury and the rediscovery of my love for reading and writing, I never would have gotten over the fact that I would no longer be able to play the sport I had grown up with. Of course I still love the game, my love for reading saved me from the pain of being unable to play.

I would work on my shot at home, practice at variosus basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I may not have been the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side, her voice was etched with concern.

   Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The refferee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play.

   The quote I had heard from my schools band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach theres no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only temperary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine."

   I wasn't. If only I had walked away in that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldn't have had to go through such trials that followed.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down that old basketball court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear that I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had went to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my miniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consisticy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheelchair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   Everything felt out of touch, out of reality, that was until I picked up a book again. The words floating across the page, illustrating fantastical worlds of vast civilations and strange abilites came to life. It played through my mind as a movie would be shown on a screen. I found my motivation. A motivation to write, to read, and to draw. Although I never got too far in my writing, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas that excited me. 

   I eventually picked up art and began attempting to draw the characters I created and the worlds I invisioned. None of them were perfect, but then again, neither is anything else in this world.

   My love for reading gave me an escape from the pains of the real world and opened a new pathway to opprotunities to improve my creative abilities. Without my injury and the rediscovery of my love for reading and writing, I never would have gotten over the fact that I would no longer be able to play the sport I had grown up with. Of course I still love the game, my love for reading saved me from the pain of being unable to play.

When the Going Gets Rough

   Tick, tock.

   Tick, tock.

   Tick... Tap tap, tap tap, tap.

   It was the first test of the day and all I could focus on was the tick tick ticking of the classroom clock hanging on the wall, the tapping of pencils against the desks and the uncomfortable squeaky chair that seemed to find mischievous joy in my discomfort. Time was fading and I still had over half of the test to go. I would have to stay after again; work through the bell and the sounds of everyone around me packing up for their next class. It's so unfair. Why can't I be like them? I can always hear them speaking and moving about with no concern for my own concentration. Why did they always have to make such a ruckus? Wait, did I have homework for any of my classes tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? What did I eat earlier? Crap, focus. I have to finish the test!

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave followed by all the students from the next class that come filing in, very rarely with any concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementary years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfaction seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book outloud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didn't like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had origionally learned about the english language starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. It's so unfair. Why can't I be like them? I can always hear them speaking and moving about with no concern for my own concentration. Why did they always have to make such a ruckus? Wait, did I have homework for any of my classes tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? What did I eat earlier? Crap, focus. I have to finish the test!

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave followed by all the students from the next class that come filing in, very rarely with any concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementary years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfaction seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book out loud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didn't like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had originally learned about the English language and grammatical rules starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. This class helped me grow in ways I never believed I could and because my mother never gave up on my education, I refuse to let her down.

   I had developed a mindset that not only affected my effort towards school, but also my energy that was put into other activities like sports. Although I had a strong mindset, it began to change as I became attached to a newer, more detrimental one. 

   Through my middle school and junior high years, I was a part of the school basketball team. Before games, while everyone was getting in the mindset to play, I would have a book in my hand. Everyone thought it was strange that I would read before the games and although I knew how they perceved me, I also knew that I was one of the hardest working individuals on the team. I would work on my shot at home, practice at variosus basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I may not have been the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side, her voice was etched with concern.

   Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The refferee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play.

   The quote I had heard from my schools band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach theres no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only temperary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine."

   I wasn't. If only I had walked away in that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldn't have had to go through such trials that followed.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down that old basketball court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear that I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had went to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my miniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consisticy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheelchair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   Everything felt out of touch, out of reality, that was until I picked up a book again. The words floating across the page, illustrating fantastical worlds of vast civilations and strange abilites came to life. It played through my mind as a movie would be shown on a screen. I found my motivation. A motivation to write, to read, and to draw. Although I never got too far in my writing, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas that excited me. 

   I eventually picked up art and began attempting to draw the characters I created and the worlds I invisioned. None of them were perfect, but then again, neither is anything else in this world.

   My love for reading gave me an escape from the pains of the real world and opened a new pathway to opprotunities to improve my creative abilities. Without my injury and the rediscovery of my love for reading and writing, I never would have gotten over the fact that I would no longer be able to play the sport I had grown up with. Of course I still love the game, my love for reading saved me from the pain of being unable to play.

I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheelchair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   Everything felt out of touch, out of reality, that was until I picked up a book again. The words floating across the page, illustrating fantastical worlds of vast civilations and strange abilites came to life. It played through my mind as a movie would be shown on a screen. I found my motivation. A motivation to write, to read, and to draw. Although I never got too far in my writing, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas that excited me. 

   I eventually picked up art and began attempting to draw the characters I created and the worlds I invisioned. None of them were perfect, but then again, neither is anything else in this world.

   My love for reading gave me an escape from the pains of the real world and opened a new pathway to opprotunities to improve my creative abilities. Without my injury and the rediscovery of my love for reading and writing, I never would have gotten over the fact that I would no longer be able to play the sport I had grown up with. Of course I still love the game, my love for reading saved me from the pain of being unable to play.
answerVersions.2023-10-06T06:00:58.829Z:
When the Going Gets Rough

   Tick, tock.

   Tick, tock.

   Tick... Tap tap, tap tap, tap.

   It was the first test of the day and all I could focus on was the tick tick ticking of the classroom clock hanging on the wall, the tapping of pencils against the desks and the uncomfortable squeaky chair that seemed to find mischievous joy in my discomfort. Time was fading and I still had over half of the test to go. I would have to stay after again; work through the bell and the sounds of everyone around me packing up for their next class. It's so unfair. Why can't I be like them? I can always hear them speaking and moving about with no concern for my own concentration. Why did they always have to make such a ruckus? Wait, did I have homework for any of my classes tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? What did I eat earlier? Crap, focus. I have to finish the test!

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave followed by all the students from the next class that come filing in, very rarely with any concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementary years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfaction seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book out loud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didn't like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had originally learned about the English language and grammatical rules starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. This class helped me grow in ways I never believed I could and because my mother never gave up on my education, I refuse to let her down.

   I had developed a mindset that not only affected my effort towards school, but also my energy that was put into other activities like sports. Although I had a strong mindset, it began to change as I became attached to a newer, more detrimental one. 

   Through my middle school and junior high years, I was a part of the school basketball team. Before games, while everyone was getting in the mindset to play, I would have a book in my hand. Everyone thought it was strange that I would read before the games and although I knew how they perceived me, I also knew that I was one of the hardest working individuals on the team. I would work on my shot at home, practice at various basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I may not have been the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side, her voice was etched with concern.

   Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The referee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play.

   The quote I had heard from my school's band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach there's no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only temporary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine."

   I wasn't. If only I had walked away in that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldn't have had to go through such trials that followed.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down that old basketball court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear that I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had went to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my miniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consisticy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheelchair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   Everything felt out of touch, out of reality, that was until I picked up a book again. The words floating across the page, illustrating fantastical worlds of vast civilations and strange abilites came to life. It played through my mind as a movie would be shown on a screen. I found my motivation. A motivation to write, to read, and to draw. Although I never got too far in my writing, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas that excited me. 

   I eventually picked up art and began attempting to draw the characters I created and the worlds I invisioned. None of them were perfect, but then again, neither is anything else in this world.

   My love for reading gave me an escape from the pains of the real world and opened a new pathway to opprotunities to improve my creative abilities. Without my injury and the rediscovery of my love for reading and writing, I never would have gotten over the fact that I would no longer be able to play the sport I had grown up with. Of course I still love the game, my love for reading saved me from the pain of being unable to play.

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side, her voice was etched with concern.

   Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The referee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play.

   The quote I had heard from my school's band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach there's no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only temporary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine."

   I wasn't. If only I had walked away at that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldn't have had to go through such trials that followed.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down that old basketball court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear that I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had gone to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my meniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excrusciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consisticy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheelchair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   Everything felt out of touch, out of reality, that was until I picked up a book again. The words floating across the page, illustrating fantastical worlds of vast civilations and strange abilites came to life. It played through my mind as a movie would be shown on a screen. I found my motivation. A motivation to write, to read, and to draw. Although I never got too far in my writing, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas that excited me. 

   I eventually picked up art and began attempting to draw the characters I created and the worlds I invisioned. None of them were perfect, but then again, neither is anything else in this world.

   My love for reading gave me an escape from the pains of the real world and opened a new pathway to opprotunities to improve my creative abilities. Without my injury and the rediscovery of my love for reading and writing, I never would have gotten over the fact that I would no longer be able to play the sport I had grown up with. Of course I still love the game, my love for reading saved me from the pain of being unable to play.

When the Going Gets Rough

   Tick, tock.

   Tick, tock.

   Tick... Tap tap, tap tap, tap.

   It was the first test of the day and all I could focus on was the tick tick ticking of the classroom clock hanging on the wall, the tapping of pencils against the desks and the uncomfortable squeaky chair that seemed to find mischievous joy in my discomfort. Time was fading and I still had over half of the test to go. I would have to stay after again; work through the bell and the sounds of everyone around me packing up for their next class. It's so unfair. Why can't I be like them? I can always hear them speaking and moving about with no concern for my own concentration. Why did they always have to make such a ruckus? Wait, did I have homework for any of my classes tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? What did I eat earlier? Crap, focus. I have to finish the test!

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave followed by all the students from the next class that come filing in, very rarely with any concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementary years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfaction seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book out loud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didn't like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had originally learned about the English language and grammatical rules starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. This class helped me grow in ways I never believed I could and because my mother never gave up on my education, I refuse to let her down.

   I had developed a mindset that not only affected my effort towards school, but also my energy that was put into other activities like sports. Although I had a strong mindset, it began to change as I became attached to a newer, more detrimental one. 

   Through my middle school and junior high years, I was a part of the school basketball team. Before games, while everyone was getting in the mindset to play, I would have a book in my hand.    The quote I had heard from my school's band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach there's no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only temporary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine."

   I wasn't. If only I had walked away at that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldn't have had to go through such trials that followed.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down that old basketball court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear that I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had gone to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my meniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excruciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consistecy of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheelchair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do. All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   Everything felt out of touch, out of reality, that was until I picked up a book again. The words floating across the page, illustrating fantastical worlds of vast civilations and strange abilites came to life. It played through my mind as a movie would be shown on a screen. I found my motivation. A motivation to write, to read, and to draw. Although I never got too far in my writing, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas that excited me. 

   I eventually picked up art and began attempting to draw the characters I created and the worlds I invisioned. None of them were perfect, but then again, neither is anything else in this world.

   My love for reading gave me an escape from the pains of the real world and opened a new pathway to opprotunities to improve my creative abilities. Without my injury and the rediscovery of my love for reading and writing, I never would have gotten over the fact that I would no longer be able to play the sport I had grown up with. Of course I still love the game, my love for reading saved me from the pain of being unable to play.

I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementary years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfaction seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book out loud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didn't like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had originally learned about the English language and grammatical rules starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. This class helped me grow in ways I never believed I could and because my mother never gave up on my education, I refuse to let her down.

   I had developed a mindset that not only affected my effort towards school, but also my energy that was put into other activities like sports. Although I had a strong mindset, it began to change as I became attached to a newer, more detrimental one. 

   Through my middle school and junior high years, I was a part of the school basketball team. Before games, while everyone was getting in the mindset to play, I would have a book in my hand. Everyone thought it was strange that I would read before the games and although I knew how they perceived me, I also knew that I was one of the hardest working individuals on the team. I would work on my shot at home, practice at various basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I may not have been the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side, her voice was etched with concern.

   Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The referee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play.

   The quote I had heard from my school's band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach there's no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only temporary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine."

   I wasn't. If only I had walked away at that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldn't have had to go through such trials that followed.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down that old basketball court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear that I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had gone to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my meniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excruciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consistency of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheelchair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do? All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   Everything felt out of touch, out of reality, that was until I picked up a book again. The words floating across the page, illustrating fantastical worlds of vast civilizations and strange abilities came to life. It played through my mind as a movie would be shown on a screen. I found my motivation. A motivation to write, to read, and to draw. Although I never got too far in my writing, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas that excited me. 

   I eventually picked up art and began attempting to draw the characters I created and the worlds I envisioned. None of them were perfect, but then again, neither is anything else in this world. 

   My love for reading gave me an escape from the pains of the real world and opened a new pathway to opportunities to improve my creative abilities. Without my injury and the rediscovery of my love for reading and writing, I never would have gotten over the fact that I would no longer be able to play the sport I had grown up with. Of course I still love the game, my love for reading saved me from the pain of being unable to play.

I found my motivation. A motivation to write, to read, and to draw. Although I never got too far in my writing, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas that excited me. 

   I eventually picked up art and began attempting to draw the characters I created and the worlds I envisioned. None of them were perfect, but then again, neither is anything else in this world. 

   My love for reading gave me an escape from the pains of the real world and opened a new pathway to opportunities to improve my creative abilities. Without my injury and the rediscovery of my love for reading and writing, I never would have gotten over the fact that I would no longer be able to play the sport I had grown up with. Of course I still love the game, my love for reading saved me from the pain of being unable to play.
answerVersions.2023-10-06T06:33:05.981Z:
When the Going Gets Rough

   Tick, tock.

   Tick, tock.

   Tick... Tap tap, tap tap, tap.

   It was the first test of the day and all I could focus on was the tick tick ticking of the classroom clock hanging on the wall, the tapping of pencils against the desks and the uncomfortable squeaky chair that seemed to find mischievous joy in my discomfort. Time was fading and I still had over half of the test to go. I would have to stay after again; work through the bell and the sounds of everyone around me packing up for their next class. It's so unfair. Why can't I be like them? I can always hear them speaking and moving about with no concern for my own concentration. Why did they always have to make such a ruckus? Wait, did I have homework for any of my classes tonight? Do I need to pick up my siblings this afternoon? What did I eat earlier? Crap, focus. I have to finish the test!

   This anxious feeling has always been a prominent intrusion to my everyday life. The fear of having to stay in a class to finish a test or assignment while my classmates pack their things to leave followed by all the students from the next class that come filing in, very rarely with any concern for my presence. I always thought they were silently judging me. Why is it taking her so long? Shouldn't she be done already? We just want to talk, why won't she just finish? She's so slow. I always believed that they had to be thinking these things about me. I mean, I was thinking about it. If they didn't think the same, then what makes their minds so different from my own. Why is mine so critical?

   My passion for reading and writing did not come about until after my elementary years. Of course, many young children do not find joy in reading, but my lack of satisfaction seemed to swell as I entered even my middle school years. I couldn't focus or understand what was being said and reading a book out loud was an even harder struggle. It wasn't until my mother convinced the school to finailly test me for dyslexia that I began to understand why I didn't like reading. 

   My dyslexia teacher retaught me and a small group of students almost everything we had originally learned about the English language and grammatical rules starting from the year we began dyslexia therapy in fifth grade up to the day we finished the class in my junior year of high school. This class helped me grow in ways I never believed I could and because my mother never gave up on my education, I refuse to let her down.

   I had developed a mindset that not only affected my effort towards school, but also my energy that was put into other activities like sports. Although I had a strong mindset, it began to change as I became attached to a newer, more detrimental one. 

   Through my middle school and junior high years, I was a part of the school basketball team. Before games, while everyone was getting in the mindset to play, I would have a book in my hand. Everyone thought it was strange that I would read before the games and although I knew how they perceived me, I also knew that I was one of the hardest working individuals on the team. I would work on my shot at home, practice at various basketball camps, and even play in games with my own summer team. I may not have been the best, but I wanted to outwork every other member there. I was on a steady climb until the summer before my eighth grade year. 

   "Adrienne! Are you okay?" My friend was by my side, her voice was etched with concern.

   Moments before, I had been pushed into the wall by a girl from behind while attempting to shoot a fast-break layup. My wrist was throbbing, my head was dizzy, and it felt like I would have a nasty bruise on my knee.

   The referee stood over me, "Can you shoot the free throws or do you need to be taken out?" Taken out? No! Never. I wanted to play.

   The quote I had heard from my school's band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach there's no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only temporary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine."

   I wasn't. If only I had walked away at that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldn't have had to go through such trials that followed.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down that old basketball court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear that I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had gone to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my meniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excruciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consistency of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheelchair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do? All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   Everything felt out of touch, out of reality, that was until I picked up a book again. The words floating across the page, illustrating fantastical worlds of vast civilizations and strange abilities came to life. It played through my mind as a movie would be shown on a screen. I found my motivation. A motivation to write, to read, and to draw. Although I never got too far in my writing, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas that excited me. 

   I eventually picked up art and began attempting to draw the characters I created and the worlds I envisioned. None of them were perfect, but then again, neither is anything else in this world. 

   My love for reading gave me an escape from the pains of the real world and opened a new pathway to opportunities to improve my creative abilities. Without my injury and the rediscovery of my love for reading and writing, I never would have gotten over the fact that I would no longer be able to play the sport I had grown up with. Of course I still love the game and play with friends when I can, but my love for reading saved me from the pain of feeli

   The quote I had heard from my school's band recited in my head. 'Pain is worth the gain.' I couldn't sit out, with this coach there's no promise I would be put back in again. This pain was only temporary, I had to prove that nothing could stop me from doing my best.

   I stood, shaking off the pain in my wrist and ignoring the throbbing in my head. "Yeah, I'm fine."

   I wasn't. If only I had walked away at that moment. Allowed the athletic trainer to look at my injuries. Maybe I wouldn't have had to go through such trials that followed.

   For the next two years, I lived by that quote. "Pain is worth the gain" I ran up and down that old basketball court every day, played as hard as I could in every game I had the chance to be put into, and yet it was all in vain. At first, It was just a three month rest and I was back to playing in no time. Of course, I ignored the pain that never truly went away in fear that I would have to sit out longer. Two years later though, I was in a hospital awaiting my first of two surgeries. I knew my life would never be the same.

   I had gone to the doctor after complaining about knee problems once again. With an x-ray, they realized that I had been playing with a fractured knee and tear in my meniscus for the past two years. They said the pain should have been excruciating, not something I should have been able to have just shrugged off. After the first surgery, they determined the bone was the consistency of cottage cheese and that I would need a new one. I would have to wait for someone to die in order to be able to have a working knee once again. It of course was not ideal, but there was no other option. It was either surgery or live in pain until my knee would eventually give out, leaving me in crutches or even a wheelchair.

   It had been months since I had practiced anything. No running, no shooting, no dribbling, nothing. I knew my strength was dwindling and with it was my motivation. Without basketball, what would I do? All I had was school and basketball, I never needed anything else, so why was this happening to me?

   Everything felt out of touch, out of reality, that was until I picked up a book again. The words floating across the page, illustrating fantastical worlds of vast civilizations and strange abilities came to life. It played through my mind as a movie would be shown on a screen. I found my motivation. A motivation to write, to read, and to draw. Although I never got too far in my writing, it was the motivation to come up with new ideas that excited me. 

   I eventually picked up art and began attempting to draw the characters I created and the worlds I envisioned. None of them were perfect, but then again, neither is anything else in this world. 

   My love for reading gave me an escape from the pains of the real world and opened a new pathway to opportunities to improve my creative abilities. Without my injury and the rediscovery of my love for reading and writing, I never would have gotten over the fact that I would no longer be able to play the sport I had grown up with. Of course I still love the game and play with friends when I can, but my love for reading saved me from the pain of feeling entirely useless.
